20 April 2020

Living (and working) at home

This is a post that‚Äôs been around my head for weeks, yet finding the motivation or even want to write it has been impossible. I‚Äôve wanted to record how I feel, how, as a family, we are handling this situation but not really wanting to face my own feelings.
I‚Äôm unsure why - those that know me I‚Äôm a very open book, happy to share my emotional state at a drop of a hat.

But, here we are - many weeks after being made to work from home and I‚Äôve finally found the want to write.

From memory, it was a Wednesday that we found out we were to stop working from the office and start to do the 9 to 5 shift from home, from my office - well a room that is too small to be anything but an office.

It started out being incredibly exciting, working from home, right? I‚Äôve done this before, in fact, I had almost 3 years of it ‚Äì but this was totally different, it was remote working, not WFH.

It turned out to be the complete opposite of what I‚Äôd experienced ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt have an adventurous 4-year-old daughter, we didn‚Äôt have ‚Äúa family business‚Äù to run which has gone from strength to strength and before Covid, it was hitting heights we couldn‚Äôt dream of and, well people love the products so we can definitely say we have been busy.

Work has been tough to manage, it‚Äôs been meeting heavy ‚Äì I‚Äôve somehow morphed into a consultant for ‚Äúhow the design process should be done‚Äù, which is bloody amazing and something I‚Äôve worked so hard on for the past 6 years, and noticed for this within a place like DWP is such a great thing, and to be noticed and recommended by other people is the best, but the challenge has been the meetings ‚Äì video meetings have been a drain and quite a strain on sharing parental duties.

Whilst, we are here, let‚Äôs talk about my daughter ‚Äì without her silliness, without her energy, without her innocence in all of this I think I would have been overwhelmed by all of this, I am incredibly lucky to have ‚Äúlocked-down‚Äù with my child, and even at her worst, she makes me my absolute best.

Also, it turns out she has my sense of humour, she is as a crazy as I am with her impressions, her random animal noises and ability to really find humour in the silliest of things and bring light to the room ‚Äì but try telling that to my wife as a 37 year old man is chasing a 4 year old around the house shouting

‚ÄúARRR IMMA MAKE YOU WALK DA PLANK LADY/LAD CATTELL‚Äù

with her on a horse and me riding a broomstick.

Just imagine living with that for a moment.

The bad

I have had a lot of conversations, supportive conversations with colleagues, friends, and my wife to help handle this pressure of having ‚Äúspare time‚Äù that doesn‚Äôt really exist, the guilt of ‚Äúhome-schooling‚Äù and the general panic that spreads through a different schedule. Most find it tough to handle, I‚Äôve struggled in the last couple of days and some have a situation that is tough to relate too, but being there is the most I can do for them and I know they feel supported.

BUT: People telling me I should whip up another skill during this time, heck yeah let me learn to develop an app and read ‚Äúthe top 20 books all designers should read‚Äù, whilst teaching my child to spell her name using chalk, make dinner, walk the dog, shave my head and‚Ä¶ oh shit yeah, do my day job.

Looking back at this phase in our lives, I am sure we shall see a time of change, a change of pace, a change of priorities, a time of panic, a time of valuing the importance of having good friends, a good family and the need to support others and ourselves through hurdles that appear out of no-where.

In all the darkness, I‚Äôve found myself closer to friends, I‚Äôve found a chance to refocus, I‚Äôve found out I REALLY love helping and mentoring others, my family is as close as it‚Äôs ever been, I‚Äôve been reminded that my wife is a fucking superstar - not only is she running a business but she‚Äôs also running the house and enabling my child to be an absolute rockstar.

It‚Äôs been rough, it‚Äôs been annoying, it‚Äôs been safe for us all, it‚Äôs also been insightful and I‚Äôm actually thankful that I can learn something from what is a sad, terrible experience for us all.

Stay safe, it‚Äôs ok to be overwhelmed and it‚Äôs also ok to struggle or thrive.
